comparison: label
comments: label

comparison: background
comments: background

cohort: cohort - any characteristics of the population(s) studied, besides age
age_min: age of youngest subject including both cases and controls
age_max: age of oldest subject including both case and controls
number_subjects: number of subjects - count of case plus control subjects used in the measurement.
method: primary experimental method used to measure the response
response_component: response component - genes, proteins, cell types etc. are the entities whose change with infection is being measured
is_model: is model - signature is derived from a computational model
comparison: comparison (affected vs control, correlated variable, time vs baseline event)
time_point: time relative to baseline event at which response was measured
exposure_material: exposure material - e.g. pathogen causing disease
exposure_material_id: exposure material id, e.g. NCBI taxonomy ID
exposure_process: exposure process - method by which immune exposure occurred
disease_stage: disease stage - reported disease stage(s) of affected subjects
signature_source: signature source - figure, table or text section
comments: comments and additional details

tissue_type: As reported. Only one entry allowed.
tissue_type_term_id: Choose from list or lookup Cell Ontology code
method: Choose from list. Only one entry expected. You can add new methods.
response_component: Gene or protein symbols can be separted with commas, spaces, or semicolons. Cell types or other names must be separated using semicolons.
response_behavior_type: Choose from list. Only one entry allowed.
response_behavior: Choose from list. Only one entry allowed. Add new behaviors if required.
comparison: Free text. Use "vs" rather than a dash to separate comparison terms (A vs B).  Separate multiple comparison entries with semicolons (A vs B; C vs D).
baseline_time_event: Free text. Use "none" if no time was reported.
time_point: Number. Use "none" if no time was reported.
exposure_material: NCBI taxonomy term name, or free text
exposure_material_id: NCBI Taxonomy ID. Choose from list.
exposure_process: Choose from list. Enter new process if needed.
publication_reference_url: The URL only, not any associated display text
signature_source: Free text. Up to two entries, separated by semicolons
signature_source_url: The URL only, not any associated display text. Up to two entries, separated by semicolon
comments: Free text, limit of 255 characters

cohort: Any characteristics of the population(s) studied, besides age. Example:  Hong Kong, Atlanta. Also report if the result was limited to a subgroup of the tested cohort, e.g.  - subjects suffering adverse events  - particular threshold levels of antibody titer level - based on a receiving a particular treatment
age_min: include both case/affected and control subjects
age_max: include both case/affected and control subjects
number_subjects: Often differs by signature within a publication. If number of subjects for a particular signature is not clear in text, use total for cohort.
tissue_type: The parent tissue of the response components. Report multiple tissues in different rows. For cell-type results, the tissue is often PBMCs. For gene expression, the tissue might be a particular cell-type.
tissue_type_term_id: If there is no matching cell type in the pulldown list, the curator can try to look up a matching term in the  Cell Ontology.
method: The primary experimental method used to measure the response, e.g.  RNA-seq, CyTOF, CITE-seq.
response_component: Please copy symbols and names exactly as reported in the publication - except spell out greek letters. For cell types, this includes all markers.  Examples for a signature with three cell types: T cells CD3+/CD4+/Ki67+; T cells CD3+/CD8+/Ki67+ CD86+ myeloid dendritic cell (DC); CD86+ monocyte
is_model: Were the response components chosen using a classification or other model-building strategy?
response_behavior_type: The type of change being measured, e.g. gene expression, cell-type frequency.
response_behavior: Common values in the pulldown list: - up, down - positively correlated, negatively correlated, correlated - positively predictive, negatively predictive, predictive
comparison: Comparisons are typically between two groups, or may reflect a correlation of the response component with some other measured variable. Only report significant results. Examples: - severe COVID-19 cases vs healthy - moderate COVID-19 cases vs healthy; severe COVID-19 cases vs healthy - interferon-stimulated genes in COVID-19 vs healthy - bacterial DNA levels across COVID-19 and healthy subjects Include time comparison if relevant, e.g. 7d vs 0d, where the times are relative to the baseline reference event time (0d). Times before baseline event can be entered as negative numbers, e.g. days before vaccination (7d vs -1d). **Please be concise.**
baseline_time_event: The reference event from which the time of the experimental response is measured, e.g. hospital admission, onset of symptoms
time_point: Time point when response was measured, if available.
exposure_material: Enter the pathogen or vaccine underlying the immune exposure as reported in the publication
exposure_material_id: NCBI Taxonomy ID of pathogen causing disease. Use format id_type:id, e.g. ncbi_taxid:2697049
exposure_process: Method by which exposure to pathogen occurred
disease_stage: Reported disease stage(s) of affected subjects in all comparisons entered in row (not including control subjects). We will not attempt to match these directly with the comparisons.
publication_reference_id: Enter an official identifier for the article curated, using format type:id
publication_date: Use zeros for unavailable month or day
publication_reference_url: URL of the article curated. Primary source publication (e.g. Cell, Nature) preferred over PMC
signature_source: Figure, table number etc. where the signature was found, usually original primary publication rather than PMC
signature_source_url: Link to figure, table number etc. where the signature was found, usually the original primary publication rather than PMC. Please enter the URL directly, not as a hyperlinked name.
comments: Details clarifying any aspect of the signature not captured in other fields
curator_comments: Questions or notes for further examination from curator. Will not appear in Dashboard

response_component: Natural Killer cells; CD56dim Natural Killer cells
comparison: moderate COVID-19 patients vs healthy patients
comments: COVID-19 patients were sampled 5 to 24 days after symptom debut and 0 to 8 days after being admitted to the hospital. Patients classified as having moderate COVID-19 disease had oxygen saturation of 90 to 94% or were receiving 0.5 to 3 liters/min of oxygen at inclusion.

comparison: severe COVID-19 patients vs healthy patients
comments: COVID-19 patients were sampled 5 to 24 days after symptom debut and 0 to 8 days after being admitted to the hospital. Patients with severe COVID-19 disease were treated in an ICU or a high dependency unit, requiring either noninvasive or mechanical ventilation.

cohort: Atlanta, Georgia, USA & Hong Kong, China
response_component: plasmablasts of CD45 cells; effector CD8 T cells of CD8 T cells
comparison: COVID-19 infected patients vs healthy patients
comments: -healthy: samples from asymptomatic adults prior to widespread SARS-CoV-2 circulation in the community. COVID-19 patients "according to WHO guidance and positive SARS-CoV-2 RT-PCR testing by nasopharyngeal swabs". convalescent defined as "more than 4 weeks since symptom onset and currently asymptomatic. Moderate cases were defined as respiratory symptoms with radiological findings of pneumonia. Severe cases were defined as requiring supplemental oxygen. Critical cases [ICU] were organ failure necessitating intensive care unit (ICU) care. Patients with RSV and influenza were defined as acute hospitalized patients with confirmed diagnoses by BioFire FilmArray of nasopharyngeal and oropharyngeal swabs. RSV and Flu patients were classified as moderate if not requiring oxygen, severe if requiring oxygen, and critical if requiring ICU level care." from Supplemental

COVID-19 patients "according to WHO guidance and positive SARS-CoV-2 RT-PCR testing by nasopharyngeal swabs". convalescent defined as "more than 4 weeks since symptom onset and currently asymptomatic. Moderate cases were defined as respiratory symptoms with radiological findings of pneumonia. Severe cases were defined as requiring supplemental oxygen. Critical cases [ICU] were organ failure necessitating intensive care unit (ICU) care. Patients with RSV and influenza were defined as acute hospitalized patients with confirmed diagnoses by BioFire FilmArray of nasopharyngeal and oropharyngeal swabs. RSV and Flu patients were classified as moderate if not requiring oxygen, severe if requiring oxygen, and critical if requiring ICU level care." from Supplemental

comments: Significant in cell count and percentage frequency. Severe defined as "with fever, cough and ARDS [PaO2= (partial pressure of arterial oxygen)/FIO2 (Fraction of inspired oxygen) Rati0 < 300mmHg]." Mild defined as "mild conjunctivitis, axillary temperature of 37.5C, or with no clinical sign"

comparison: moderate & severe COVID-19 patients vs healthy patients
comments: Moderate was defined as: "SARS-CoV-2 infection requiring hospitalization without supplementary oxygen (1); infection requiring non-invasive supplementary oxygen (<3 l/min to maintain SpO2 >92%) (2); and infection requiring non-invasive supplementary oxygen (>3 l/min to maintain SpO2 >92%, or >2 l/min to maintain SpO2 >92% and had a high-sensitivity C-reactive protein (CRP) >70) and received tocilizumab)." Severe disease status (clinical score 4 or 5) was defined as infection meeting all criteria for clinical score 3 and also requiring admission to the ICU and >6 l/min supplementary oxygen to maintain SpO2 >92% (4); or infection requiring invasive mechanical ventilation or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) in addition to glucocorticoid or vasopressor administration (5)"

response_component: type 1 dendritic cells; type 2 dendritic cells; plasmacytoid dendritic cells; CD8+ T cells; CD4+ T cells; natural killer T cells; natural killer cells
comparison: moderate & severe COVID-19 patients vs healthy patients
comments: Moderate was defined as: "SARS-CoV-2 infection requiring hospitalization without supplementary oxygen (1); infection requiring non-invasive supplementary oxygen (<3 l/min to maintain SpO2 >92%) (2); and infection requiring non-invasive supplementary oxygen (>3 l/min to maintain SpO2 >92%, or >2 l/min to maintain SpO2 >92% and had a high-sensitivity C-reactive protein (CRP) >70) and received tocilizumab)." Severe disease status (clinical score 4 or 5) was defined as infection meeting all criteria for clinical score 3 and also requiring admission to the ICU and >6 l/min supplementary oxygen to maintain SpO2 >92% (4); or infection requiring invasive mechanical ventilation or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) in addition to glucocorticoid or vasopressor administration (5)"
